learning_outcomes.description: Explain, and research more deeply, the important features of the regulation of parliament, elections and political activity.
Structure and argue essay, seminar discussion and exam problems, applying both practical and theoretical considerations relevant to the course.
Understand the role that law and institutions play in regulating representative democracy.
Integrate the institutions and rules studied into their political and normative contexts: those contexts are important to an understanding of - and potential reform in - this field.

assessments.task_description:
This short written assignment lets students demonstrate their research and writing skills, whilst deepening their understanding of issues from the first half of the course. That is, from weeks 1-6: eg parliamentary law, the composition or distribution of parliament, representation, political participation under the constitution, or distinctive features of the franchise.

Guidelines will be released on the course website on Monday week 3. The final assignment is due Wednesday week 8. (Given the mid-semester break, that is over 6 weeks to complete it).

One week prior to the due date (ie Wednesday of week 7) you must submit a one page statement of Research Method. This will be be further explained in the guidelines and class. It is worth 4 marks or 10% of the total for the assignment. It will be marked as: 'acceptable' = 4 marks, 'on time but inadequate' = 2 marks, or 'not submitted' = 0 marks.

The guidelines will include a choice of set topics. Students may frame an alternative topic, but only after consultation with Graeme Orr as course coordinator. Such a bespoke topic must relate to issues or themes from the first half of the course. Overseas exchange students are encouraged to frame a comparative law topic (eg compare Australia and their home country on a particular issue).  

The word limit for the assignment itself is strict: no words in excess of 2200 will be marked. This limit excludes citation detail in footnotes. But such notes must not contain discursive material, eg commentary. This word limit is separate from the Research Method statement.

Given the word limit, consider a sharp focus for your essay. This may mean choosing a narrow question or aspect of a larger topic.  That said, do not just jump into a seemingly 'narrow' question, without reading and thinking 'around' the topic and its context, before framing your assignment in a focused way.

The assignment is to be submitted as a Word document, via a link on the course website. Late submission without a law school extension will be penalised at the usual rate.  

The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools in this assignment is permitted. But must be disclosed as part of your Research Method statement.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted as Word files, via the submission link on the course website. There will be a separate link to upload your Research Method statement.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The exam may consist of:

1. a normative essay linking themes in the course with a broad area of regulation,

2. a problem solving/advice question, and

3. one or more shorter questions requiring critical evaluation of some specific case's or statutory regime.

Students need to keep up with classes and readings over the course. We will discuss the format, coverage and expectations for the examination in the last two classes.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Weekly Schedule of Topics and Classes

There are 12 classes, over 13 weeks. Each with a study guide of its own. Including holiday breaks, and noting assessment dates these are:

Week 1. The law of politics. This introduces the course, the evolution of parliaments and theories about the 'purpose' of the law of politics.

Week 2. Parliament: institution and structure. This covers the structure and composition of parliaments within ideas of representation, and the context of federalism and bicameralism.

Week 3. Parliamentary law and privileges. Parliaments guard their privileges, including the absolute privilege of parliamentary speech and discipline of MPs and others for contempt.

The Research Assignment guidelines are released Monday of week 3.

Week 4. Political participation and the Constitution. Courts recognise an implied freedom of political communication and access to the franchise: but not any broader 'right' to political participation, non-discrimination or equality.

Week 5. Mapping parliaments and weighting votes. This considers the mapping of parliaments and weighting of votes involved in 'redistributions' of the seats in lower houses.

Week 6. Who can vote. This explores both the definition of the franchise, and compulsory voting rules in Australia.

Week 7. Qualifications to be elected. This focuses on candidacies: who is qualified to be an MP and restrictions on being listed on the ballot paper.

The Research Method statement and the Research Assignment are due on Wednesday of week 7 and week 8, respectively.

There is no class Monday 6 April due to Easter and the mid-semester break between weeks 7 and 8.

Week 8. Political parties under the law. This examines how the law impacts (or enables) the internal affairs of parties within the idea of freedom of association.

Week 9. Regulation of campaigning and misinformation. This considers the (limited) legal norms constraining either the form or content of electoral speech.

There is no class in week 10 due to Monday 4 May being Labour Day holiday.

Week 11. The courts' role in electoral politics. This covers judicial involvement in disputed elections or administration.

Week 12. Money in politics. This focuses on the new system for national elections and participants, and the new South Australian model banning donations to parliamentary parties/MPs.

Week 13. Referendums and direct democracy + Exam overview. This briefly considers how and why referendums or plebiscites are held. Plus exam coverage and a past exam question.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04
